well, the lens in your eye is cell based, which is water, but with a LOT of protein in solution (like hundreds of mgs/ml). This high protein concentration give the solution a high index of refraction, making a good lens material. The proteins are called crystallins, which are actually just house keeping proteins repurposed for lens development by evolution because they can exist at such high concentrations. Even more cool- the cells in the lens are super regularly packed, and the central cells get rid of all of their organelles, to increase optical clarity. Even MORE cool is that the refractive index isn't even uniform across, and the lens deforms ("accomodates") to focus on different distances. The visual system of vertebrates actually use two lens elements- the lens and the cornea, which is also super cool- how it arranges its collagen fibers to be clear, not opaque (like the sclera, which is white due to a different collagen arrangement). And even MORE cool is... oh. Wait. No one is even reading this.  Derp.

So, the surface tension causes the water surface to make a lens.
As you move the straw up and down, it actually will cause the SURFACE of the water in the straw to rise and lower. This is because the bottom of the straw is going to be at a different pressure due to it's different depth, and will raise the waters surface in the straw at depth, and lower the surface of the water in the straw when the submerged end is shallow. The difference between the two surface levels will change the focal length of the 'lens' and cause more or less magnification.

"Surface tension" creates a CONVEX lens as the straw is pushed down into the water; a CONCAVE lens is created as the straw is lifted. Alcohol has little or no surface tension based on its solution dilution(i.e. 50% rubbing alcohol vs 70% or 90%). A product by Shaklee called "Basic H" breaks down the surface tension of water without adding color or changing viscosity; improving the ability of water to permeate  porous materials which makes it great as an additive to laundry. This product, Basic H, would negate the lensing effect displayed in this video. Cool, huh?

Adhesives is a great example with many complex variations based on applications; for those who wish to explore this science further. But one interesting poke into this curiosity stream is the way a soap molecule works. I don't just mean the experiments of how the surface tension of water can be changed by introducing a drop of soap, although that is a good one to be familiar with. But there are mechanics to why a soap molecule tends to attach to surfaces and absorb all particulates at one temperature and then at another temperature, completely closes up and releases from all surfaces.

What you're actually witnessing here is a case of dynamic wetting. It still is a relatively open subject, despite the first models appearing in the 70s. It's part of the subject of my PhD, since it is often applied in industrial context (coatings and such). We still don't fully grasp how the contact angle evolves with the velocity of the triple line, some models describe it as a hydrodynamic phenomenon involving viscosity, other as a statistical physics with atoms "jumpin" at the triple line where the three phases meet. Extremely interesting stuff, you should read about it if you're interested. We don't even fully know what the triple line looks like - the contact angle depends on the scale at which it is considered, from nanometric to millimetric scales!

Water does this because it's a very polar molecule: the difference in electromagnetic charge from one side of the molecule to the other is fairly high, especially for such a small and low-weight molecule. This polarity in turn is a consequence of the way oxygen likes to form two bonds at a 120-degree angle to each other, the reasons for which get pretty deep into the weeds, requiring an understanding of atomic structure that goes beyond the undergrad-level version of the electron shell model, let alone the ridiculously oversimplistic Bohr model we all learned in high school.

In the undergrad-level model, the first shell holds two electrons, and the second can hold up to eight, which would suggest, to a naive analysis, slots at multiples of ninety degrees to each other on a three-dimensional atom. The truth is much more complicated: subatomic particles, such as electrons, do not behave as macroscopic objects, so they don't have exactly fixed properties like shape and size and color and smoothness and exact position (relative to other particles in the same atom) in quite the same way as the marble or tennis ball (or, heaven help us, entire planet) that most people visualize. The reason for the 120-degree angle is apparently somewhat complicated, and I've never seen a really clear explanation for it.

"Water" lenses are actually also used to produce most high-end microchips you find in your devices today. "Wet" immersion lithography works by replacing the gap between the lens and the chip wafer with a liquid and using its refractive index to more precisely focus the light and the chip pattern onto the wafer.

It's one of the tricks that has allowed the semiconductor industry to continue using relatively wide 193nm DUV wavelength light sources to create structures down to a 7nm scale. Next-generation 7nm process nodes and beyond will use the newest, much smaller 13.5nm EUV light source, where immersion techniques will remain out of the question (for now) due to the fact that EUV light is absorbed by almost anything and thus requires a vacuum to work properly. In fact, EUV technology requires specially shaped mirrors instead of lenses to focus the light, since the lens itself would already absorb this almost X-ray spectrum light.

The magnifying lens is convex (the bulging shape) or converging (description of the path is parallel light rays as they pass through the lens). Converging lenses are used to make glasses for far sighted eyes. They can also be used to start a fire using sunlight. The second lens is concaved (the hollowed out or caved in shape), or diverging (because parallel light rays bend apart as they pass through). Diverging lenses are used to make glasses for near sighted eyes and cannot be used to make fire from sunlight. (Sorry, fans of Lord of the Flies. The kid couldn't have started fire because the author didn't know physics).

Fun trivia, they use water as a magnifier to make all the chips of '14 nm' and larger, even the current TSMC 7 nm chips are made with water as a magnifier. Immersion-lithography, basically pictures with an extreme magnification, because the wavelength of the used light is too high for the desired small size water is being used as a magnifier. With EUV they wavelength of the light is smaller but generating that is extremely difficult so it took a long time to get it developed for mass scale production.
